subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
author: April Abercrombie
full_text:
------=_NextPart_000_0010_01C9D184.07602700
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Admittedly I do not know much about bit-level comparisons, what they can or=
 can't show so I will have to leave that to you. I have doubts because I wo=
rry once a file's integrity has been messed with, I wonder that even though=
 the bits match, maybe that doesn't mean they are the same quality as the o=
riginal. I really don't know though what is possible or impossible when it =
comes to this area.

"It is probably possible to set up an email compressio=
n scheme that does do lossy audio compression.  My tests show my setup does=
 not.  If you'd like me to help test your setup, we can do that too. From w=
hat I see, lossy compression from an attachment would be very unusual."

Th=
e problem I have is that not just from Jon, but I have heard it from other =
people, and a professional and they all said that loss is possible. From al=
l that, my conclusion was that maybe in some cases loss was possible.

Howe=
ver, your arguments do put doubt back into my mind, which pisses me off, be=
cause I had originally argued feverishly for no loss, then I heard differen=
t from different sources and decided to do what I thought was the right thi=
ng by contacting a third party professional. So after all that, I decided I=
 was licked and had to eat crow.

Now I am back at square one, from the oth=
er side LOL!!! Computer people have been wrong in the past.


"It is probab=
ly possible to set up an email compression scheme that does do lossy audio =
compression.  My tests show my setup does not.  If you'd like me to help te=
st your setup, we can do that too. From what I see, lossy compression from =
an attachment would be very unusual."

I have not tested it from my compute=
r, as I haven't had any problems with loss. I would really like to have Jon=
 work with us on this, because he was the original person who told me I was=
 wrong.

But I will test it from my side. I will send a wav file to one of =
my other addresses. Then I will download and compare. If I think I hear a d=
ifference, then maybe I can have you do a bit-level comparison on the files=
.

Either way, I am going to get to the bottom of this.



  ----- Original=
 Message ----- 
  From: Rj 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, =
May 10, 2009 2:59 PM
  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTIO=
N JON





        Yes you can tell loss of quality by a bit-level comparis=
on.  An audio file is just a file of bytes, that is later interpreted by an=
 audio player.  Two files with the exact same contents, whether they are au=
dio or image or a dababase or an exe, are indistinguishable from each other=
.  That is, if I copied the contents of one to a new file, and the contents=
 of the other to a new file, and asked you which file each came from, there=
 would be no way to tell.  Even the audio player could not tell.  The data =
is identical, and so the sound (or the picture, etc) would be identical.

 =
       Yes I did listen to the results, but that is not the best test (they=
 sounded identical, but that is a subjective opinion).  The real test is co=
mpring the contents.  Identical contents means indentical data, means ident=
ical audio.

        It is probably possible to set up an email compression=
 scheme that does do lossy audio compression.  My tests show my setup does =
not.  If you'd like me to help test your setup, we can do that too. From wh=
at I see, lossy compression from an attachment would be very unusual.


   =
     --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombieghostresearch=
.com> wrote:


          From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombieghostres=
earch.com>
          Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION =
JON
          To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
          Date: Sunday, May 10, 2=
009, 1:50 PM



          I have not personally experienced the loss myself=
. Jon from this list is the one who originally told me about it. I have als=
o heard of it happening to a few other people. After my conversation with J=
on, I talked to a computer professional, and he told me that you can experi=
ence loss in attached files.

          I don't know if you would be able t=
o tell loss of quality in an audio file with a bit-level comparison. Just b=
ecause the data has been replaced, doesn't have to mean it is perfect.

   =
       Did you listen to the before and after results?

          Jon-Pleas=
e relay your experience with the loss of quality on emailed files.


      =
      ----- Original Message ----- 
            From: Rj 
            To: E=
VP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
            Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 2:38 PM
   =
         Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules


                  I =
can't vouch for your computer or servers, but I just did some tests, and se=
nt a 2.1MB wav file from MSN to Yahoo and back, once allowing compression, =
and once turning it off.   I was able to verify that one was compressed and=
 one was not, by checking the sizes when they arrived at Yahoo. Once they c=
ame back to MSN, I then did a bit-level comparison of the original, and the=
 ones sent around email.  They were all identical, which indicates lossless=
 compression.

                  If you have a file you'd like me to test f=
or you, let me know.  But I wouldn't take someone's word for how your serve=
r's work, without testing them yourself.



                  --- On Sun, 5=
/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


 =
                   From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch=
. com>
                    Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
    =
                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                    Date: Sund=
ay, May 10, 2009, 12:50 PM



                    For executables, you may =
be right. However, for wav files, the compression during email is not loss =
less. 

                    I used to think as you do, in that the emailed =
attachment of a wav file would not loose anything. After a lengthy discours=
e with another member here, I learned that I was wrong. The reason why I di=
d not realize it in the first place is that when I would email a wav file, =
I would intentionally keep it in very small segments, to keep file size dow=
n. This was just for ease of transfer. But because of this, I had not exper=
ienced any noticeable loss.

                    Now it may be in some case=
s, depending on the servers or what have you that the file goes through, th=
at the loss may be less or more. But once the attachment is downloaded, the=
 quality has been found to be less then the original wav.

                =
    Again though you can only really tell when the wav file is large.

    =
                ----- Original Message ----- 
                      From: R=
j 
                      To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                    =
  Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 1:36 PM
                      Subject: Re: [EV=
P-ITC] File uploading rules


                            The kind of compr=
ession that occurs during an email attachment is "lossless": it compress th=
e file cleverly without losing information.  For example, if I had a progra=
m in some .exe files, and I sent it over email, it could compress it.  But =
if it lost even one bit, the resulting exe file would not execute again aft=
er it was uncompressed on the other side.

                            This=
 kind of compression does things like looking for common patterns in the fi=
le, and replacing them with a token.  A rough example would be if it found =
"Howdy Neighbor" in a file 20 times, it could replace all the occurances wi=
th say $HN1.  And also write a little dictionary in there someplace that sa=
ys "$HN1=3DHowdy Neighbor".

                            When the file gets=
 to its destination it can be uncompressed, and all occurences of $HN1 are =
replaced with "Howdy Neighbor".  So it was compressed (instead of 14 charac=
ters each, it only needed 4, plus the dictionary), but lost no data.

     =
                       Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. are not lossless.  =
Depending on the level of compression, some level of data is lost, and so c=
annot be recovered or reconstructed later.

                            Ric=
k



                            --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <ap=
ril@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                              =
From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
            =
                  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
             =
                 To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                             =
 Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 10:26 AM



                              Anot=
her thing:

                              I recently found this out. When y=
ou email a file, if it is not saved as a compressed format, the email filte=
ring process will actually compress the file automatically.

              =
                So even if you have attached a wav. file, it will loose res=
olution over the email process. It will not sound exactly the same as the o=
riginal wav. file. How much it differs depends on the size of the file you =
are attaching. If it is a very large file, it will sound much different.

 =
                             The only exception to this is if the wav. file=
 is small enough that the filtering process will ignore it. It has to be pr=
etty small though, like under 1 MB (I am not exactly sure of the threshold)=
.

                              The best way to share files over the inter=
net if you want them as close to the original as possible is to upload them=
 directly to a website.

                                ----- Original Mes=
sage ----- 
                                From: Rj 
                     =
           To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                                Se=
nt: Sunday, May 10, 2009 10:54 AM
                                Subject: =
Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules



                                Pixel=
ization doesn't clean-up the data: it replaces it.  Imagine taking a pictur=
e of a field of flowers, and beginning to add levels or pixelization to the=
 picture.  Soon, you would not be able to tell there were flowers there at =
all.  You would see a lot of colored blocks.

                             =
   Or in the other direction, imagine you are looking at a competely random=
ize bunch of pixes on your screen: a complete screen of truely random stati=
c snow.  Pixelizing this, after a while, you would again start to see color=
ed blocks.

                                What's happening is that it is =
processing an area of the image, taking (for instance) the average value of=
 that entire area, and replacing all the blocks in that area with the avera=
ge.  In video processing, this would result in a field of multi-colored flo=
wers being replaced by, for instance, a big greyish-bluish block, with no r=
esemblance to flowers.  In the noise example, it maybe replace all the rand=
om pixels with another big greyish-bluish block.  If you did not know befor=
ehand what the original picture was, you couldn't tell whether your pixeliz=
ed image was really a field of flowers, a chevy, the sky with clouds, or a =
random bunch of pixels.

                                It works the same =
with the sound files.  Taking something as complex as speech, and replacing=
 frequencies with their averages, loses the speech the farther you go, unti=
l you head strange fluctuating square waves.  Doing the same to random stat=
ic will eventually produce the same thing.  And random fluctuating square w=
aves can sound a bit like speech - or at least, you could have fun sharing =
with each other what you thing they 'sound like'.





                    =
            --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote:=



                                From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com=
>
                                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rul=
es
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
           =
                     Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 9:29 AM


                =
                I always save the whole file in wav format then do my clips=
 as mp3. Then I have the original for analysis. 

                         =
       As far as pixelization of non sounds/white noise whos to say that is=
nt being manipulated by them as well LOL. Water is a form of white noise. I=
 seem to remember some experiments done with blank tapes/film, no recording=
 done yet there were voices/images there. I find it all interesting.

     =
                           Just a thought. Ok off to work now!
            =
                    Misty

                                --- On Sun, 5/10=
/09, Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com> wrote:


                                From=
: Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com>
                                Subject: Re: [EV=
P-ITC] File uploading rules
                                To: EVP-ITC@yah=
oogroups .com
                                Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 1=
1:47 AM


                                Be a bit careful of formats like =
mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the sounds though.   While some=
 formats (like wav) can store the audio very close to the way it was record=
ed, formats like mp3 compress the file, and in so doing lose some of the so=
nic details.  This may not be a big deal in music, where the audio is fairl=
y clear to begin with.  But with sound sources with a lot of noise (like ev=
ps), this can not only obscure any real sounds, but pixelize non-sounds (li=
ke white noise) and make them start to sound like speech.

                =
                So mp3 might be good for sharing the data, once you've alre=
ady formed an opinion based on an analysis of the wav file.  But mp3 is not=
 good as a medium for analysis.  It can lead to many false positives and mi=
sinterpretations.

                                --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Mis=
ty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote:


                                F=
rom: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com>
                                Su=
bject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                                T=
o: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                Date: Sunday, M=
ay 10, 2009, 8:26 AM


                                Thanks =3D)

       =
                          You will get the hang of it. Kristen is right tha=
ts how you save it. For most softwares its under save as or export as. If y=
ou still have trouble use one of the links I posted to help ya out.

      =
                          Misty

                <TD vAlign=
=3Dtop>I can't vouch for your computer or servers, but 
                  I=
 just did some tests, and sent a 2.1MB wav file from MSN to 
              =
    Yahoo and back, once allowing compression, and once turning it 
       =
           off.   I was able to verify that one was compressed 
 =
                 and one was not, by checking the sizes when they arrived a=
t 
                  Yahoo. Once they came back to MSN, I then did a bit-le=
vel 
                  comparison of the original, and the ones sent around=
 
                  email.  They were all identical, which indicates l=
ossless 
                  compression.<BR><BR>If you have a file you'd lik=
e me to test 
                  for you, let me know.  But I wouldn't =
take someone's word 
                  for how your server's work, without =
testing them 
                  yourself.<BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 5/1=
0/09, April 
                  Abercrombie <I><april@abercrombiegh ostre=
search.

OCKQUOTE 
                    style=3D"BORDER-LEFT: rgb(16,16,255) 2px soli=
d"><BR>From:

                    <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"My=
riad Pro">For executables, you may

for wav files, the compression during 
                    email is not los=
s less. </FONT></DIV>
                    <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myria=
d Pro"></FONT> </DIV>
                    <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"=
Myriad Pro">I used to think as you 
                    do, in that the ema=
iled attachment of a wav file would 
                    not loose any=
thing. After a lengthy discourse with another 
                    member h=
ere, I learned that I was wrong. The reason 
                    why I=
 did not realize it in the first place is that 
                    when I =
would email a wav file, I would intentionally keep it 
                    =
in very small segments, to keep file size down. This was 
                 =
   just for ease of transfer. But because of this, I had not 
             =
       experienced any noticeable loss.</FONT></DIV>
                    <D=
IV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>
                 =
   <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">Now it may be in some

     =
               file goes through, that the loss may be less or more. But 
 =
                   once the attachment is 
                    downloaded,&=
nbsp;the quality has been found to be 
                    less t=
hen the original wav.</FONT></DIV>

face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>
                    <DIV><FONT size=
=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">Again though you can 
                    only rea=
lly tell when the wav file is 
                    large.</FONT></DIV>=

nal Message ----- </DIV>

ing=3D0>
                        <TBODY>

     =
                     <TD vAlign=3Dtop>The kind of compression that occurs 
=
                            during an email attachment is "lossless": it 
 =
                           compress the file cleverly without losing 
     =
                       information.  For example, if I had a program 
=
                            in some .exe files, and I sent it over email, i=
t 
                            could compress it.  But if it lost even=
 one 
                            bit, the resulting exe file would not exe=
cute again 
                            after it was uncompressed on the ot=
her 
                            side.<BR><BR>This kind of compression does=
 things 
                            like looking for common patterns in th=
e file, and 
                            replacing them with a token. =
 A rough example 
                            would be if it found "Howdy N=
eighbor" in a file 20 
                            times, it could replace =
all the occurances with say 
                            $HN1.  And al=
so write a little dictionary in 
                            there someplac=
e that says "$HN1=3DHowdy 
                            Neighbor".<BR><BR>Wh=
en the file gets to its 
                            destination it can be =
uncompressed, and all 
                            occurences of $HN1 are r=
eplaced with "Howdy 
                            Neighbor".  So it was=
 compressed (instead of 14 
                            characters each, it=
 only needed 4, plus the 
                            dictionary), but lost=
 no data.<BR><BR>Some formats, 
                            like jpeg and m=
p3. are not lossless.  Depending 
                            on the l=
evel of compression, some level of data is 
                            los=
t, and so cannot be recovered or reconstructed 
                           =
 later.<BR><BR>Rick<BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
                        =
    5/10/09, April Abercrombie 
                            <I><april@ab=
ercrombiegh ostresearch. 
                            com></I></B> wrote=
:<BR>
                            <BLOCKQUOTE 
                            =
style=3D"BORDER-LEFT: rgb(16,16,255) 2px solid"><BR>From: 
                =
              April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh 
                  =
            ostresearch. com><BR>Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] 
               =
               File uploading rules<BR>To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups 
           =
                   .com<BR>Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 10:26 
             =
                 AM<BR><BR>
                              <DIV id=3Dyiv8198=
60743>
                              <DIV id=3Dygrp-text>
                 =
             <P></P>
                              <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=
=3D"Myriad Pro">Another 
                              thing:</FONT></DIV>
=
                              <DIV><FONT size=3D2 
                        =
      face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>
                             =
 <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">I recently 
                      =
        found this out. When you email a file, if it is 
                  =
            not saved as a compressed format, the email 
                  =
            filtering process will actually compress the file 
            =
                  automatically.</FONT></DIV>
                             =
 <DIV><FONT size=3D2 
                              face=3D"Myriad Pro"></F=
ONT> </DIV>
                              <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"=
Myriad Pro">So even if you 
                              have attached a w=
av. file, it will loose 
                              resolution over the =
email process. It will not 
                              sound exactly the=
 same as the original wav. file. 
                              How much it=
 differs depends on the size of the 
                              file you=
 are attaching. If it is a very large 
                              f=
ile, it will sound much different.</FONT></DIV>
                           =
   <DIV><FONT size=3D2 
                              face=3D"Myriad Pro"><=
/FONT> </DIV>
                              <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=
=3D"Myriad Pro">The only 
                              exception to this i=
s if the wav. file is small 
                              enough that the =
filtering process will ignore it. 
                              It has to =
be pretty small though, like under 
                              1 MB=
 (I am not exactly sure of the 
                              threshold).</=
FONT></DIV>
                              <DIV><FONT size=3D2 
            =
                  face=3D"Myriad Pro"></FONT> </DIV>
                 =
             <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">The best way 
        =
                      to share files over the internet if you want 
  =
                            them as close to the original as possible is to=
 
                              upload them directly to a website.</FONT></=
DIV>

T: normal; FONT-STYLE: normal; FONT-FAMILY: arial; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-WE=

xt>

BLE border=3D0 cellSpacing=3D0 cellPadding=3D0>
                           =
     <TBODY>
                                <TR>
                         =
       <TD vAlign=3Dtop><BR>Pixelization doesn't clean-up 
                =
                the data: it replaces it.  Imagine taking a 
         =
                       picture of a field of flowers, and beginning to 
   =
                             add levels or pixelization to the picture.&nbs=
p; 
                                Soon, you would not be able to tell the=
re were 
                                flowers there at all.  You wo=
uld see a lot 
                                of colored blocks.<BR><BR>Or=
 in the other 
                                direction, imagine you are l=
ooking at a 
                                competely randomize bunch of p=
ixes on your 
                                screen: a complete screen of =
truely random 
                                static snow.  Pixelizin=
g this, after a 
                                while, you would again sta=
rt to see colored 
                                blocks.<BR><BR>What's ha=
ppening is that it is 
                                processing an area o=
f the image, taking (for 
                                instance) the ave=
rage value of that entire area, 
                                and replac=
ing all the blocks in that area with 
                                the a=
verage.  In video processing, this 
                                wo=
uld result in a field of multi-colored flowers 
                           =
     being replaced by, for instance, a big 
                              =
  greyish-bluish block, with no resemblance to 
                           =
     flowers.  In the noise example, it maybe 
                       =
         replace all the random pixels with another big 
                  =
              greyish-bluish block.  If you did not know 
            =
                    beforehand what the original picture was, you 
        =
                        couldn't tell whether your pixelized image was 
   =
                             really a field of flowers, a chevy, the sky wi=
th 
                                clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.<BR=
><BR>It 
                                works the same with the sound file=
s.  
                                Taking something as complex as sp=
eech, and 
                                replacing frequencies with their=
 averages, loses 
                                the speech the farther yo=
u go, until you head 
                                strange fluctuating s=
quare waves.  Doing 
                                the same to rando=
m static will eventually 
                                produce the same =
thing.  And random 
                                fluctuating square=
 waves can sound a bit like 
                                speech - or at=
 least, you could have fun sharing 
                                with ea=
ch other what you thing they 'sound 
                                like'.=
<BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
                                5/1=
0/09, Misty Dawn <I><bulletbabea@ 
                                yahoo=
.com></I></B> wrote:<BR>

                                <DIV>I always save the whole file in wav f=
ormat 
                                then do my clips as mp3. Then I have=
 the 
                                original for analysis. </DIV>
       =

                                =
<DIV>As far as pixelization of non sounds/white 
                          =
      noise whos to say that isnt being manipulated by 
                   =
             them as well LOL. Water is a form of white 
                  =
              noise. I seem to remember some experiments done 
            =

                        yet there were voices/images there. I find it 
    =

ht. Ok off to work now!</DIV>

><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 5/10/09, Rj

                          =

               =
                 <TBODY>
                                <TR>
             =
                   <TD vAlign=3Dtop>Be a bit careful of formats like 
     =
                           mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the =

                                sounds though.   While some form=
ats 
                                (like wav) can store the audio very cl=
ose to the 
                                way it was recorded, formats li=
ke mp3 compress 
                                the file, and in so doing =
lose some of the sonic 
                                details.  This=
 may not be a big deal in 
                                music, where the=
 audio is fairly clear to begin 
                                with.&nbsp=
; But with sound sources with a lot of 
                                noi=
se (like evps), this can not only obscure any 
                            =
    real sounds, but pixelize non-sounds (like white 
                     =
           noise) and make them start to sound like 
                      =
          speech.<BR><BR>So mp3 might be good for sharing 
                =
                the data, once you've already formed an opinion 
          =
                      based on an analysis of the wav file.  But 
    =
                            mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis. =
 
                                It can lead to many false positives and 
=
                                misinterpretations.<BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
=
                                5/10/09, Misty Dawn <I><bulletbabea@ 
  =
                              yahoo.com></I></B> wrote:<BR>
            =
